abstract.p: Lincoln Center's American Songbook series begins on October 20 with celebration of songwriter Frank Loesser at Alice Tully Hall; photo; program will focus on songs he wrote for Hollywood in 1930's; composer Marvin Hamlisch will become first Principal Pops Conductor in 69-year history of National Symphony Orchestra in Washington; more than 70 paintings and drawings by Vincent van Gogh, which have been exhibited in Detroit and Boston, will end tour at Philadelphia Museum of Art, beginning on October 22; exhibit is described as first comprehensive museum tour devoted to full range of artist's portraiture; photo; selection of items from Smithsonian Institution's collection documenting history of visual arts in America will be shown at Archives' New York Regional Center in Manhattan; blues singer Ray Charles will help Lehman Center for the Performing Arts celebrate its 20th anniversary with performance at Lehman College in Bronx (M)

block.p: On tap are medleys from ''Guys and Dolls,'' ''Where's Charley?'' and ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.'' But even more is promised when the third season of ''Lincoln Center's American Songbook'' begins this weekend with a celebration of the songwriter Frank Loesser. Interludes between medleys will focus on songs he wrote for Hollywood in the 1930's. With Jonathan Schwartz, the series' artistic director, as host, the concerts will feature vocalists like Christine Andreas, Billy Stritch, Lilias White, Margaret Whiting and Tom Wopat. ''Heart and Soul: The Songs of Frank Loesser'' is scheduled for 8 p.m. tomorrow and Saturday in Alice Tully Hall.

The composer and conductor Marvin Hamlisch dons a new hat tomorrow. He'll become the first Principal Pops Conductor in the 69-year history of the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington. This season he will lead 9 of the 18 pops concerts, beginning this weekend with three devoted to Rodgers, Kern, Bernstein and Gershwin.

Exhibited first in Detroit, then in Boston, more than 70 paintings and drawings by Vincent van Gogh (1853-1890) will reach the final stop on their tour on Sunday when ''Van Gogh: Face to Face'' opens at the Philadelphia Museum of Art for a run through Jan. 14. Described as the first comprehensive museum show devoted to the full range of the artist's portraiture, ''Face to Face,'' with many works new to the United States, includes five arresting self-portraits.

Among the 14.6 million items at the Smithsonian Institution that document the history of the visual arts in America are letters and diaries of artists and collectors, photographs of art world figures. Today though Jan. 5, a selection of these treasures will be on view at the Archives' New York Regional Center at the PaineWebber Building, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, at 51st Street.

He sings. He plays piano. He arranges. He composes. He transformed rhythm and blues into soul. He swings. He bops. In short, if it's pop, he does it. He is Ray Charles, and at 8 p.m. tomorrow, he will help Lehman Center for the Performing Arts celebrate its 20th anniversary with a performance at Lehman College in the Bronx.
